metadata.case_name: Legal Representatives of Maharaja Bahadur Rama Rajaya Prasad Singh v. Commissioner of Income Tax

facts.text: Proceedings taken by Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Patna, against Maharaja Bahadur Rama Rajaya Prasad Singh (assessee, father of appellant) to levy income-tax for assessment year 1945-46.
ITO assessed total income at Rs. 1,60,602, including Rs. 93,604 received by assessee as interest on arrears of rent after deduction of collection charges.
Assessee urged before ITO that Rs. 93,604 not liable to tax per Patna High Court decision in Kamakshya Narain Singh v. Commissioner of Income Tax (1946) 14 ITR 673.

ITO held matter sub judice due to department's appeal to Privy Council, included amount but stayed realization of tax till Privy Council decision or March 31, 1947, under s.23(3). Order passed December 31, 1945.
Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner (AAC), Patna.
AAC on May 8, 1946, held ITO bound by Patna HC decision, set aside order re Rs.93,604, directed fresh assessment excluding it but to determine and tax non-agricultural portion.
ITO made fresh assessment under ss.23(3) and 31 on August 20, 1946, deducting whole Rs.93,604 and minor reductions.
Department did not challenge AAC order or subsequent ITO order.
Privy Council allowed department's appeal in Kamakshya Narain Singh case on July 6, 1948, holding interest on arrears of rent payable re agricultural land is not agricultural income.
ITO issued notice under s.34 on September 25, 1948, to file fresh return as income escaped assessment for year ending March 31, 1946.
Notice defective; fresh notice under amended s.34 issued March 18, 1949.
Proceedings under s.34 led to revised assessment order under ss.23(3) and 34 on April 30, 1949, adding Rs.93,604.
Assessee appealed revised order; AAC dismissed appeal July 26, 1949, holding Privy Council decision as information under s.34(1)(a) and (b), ITO had reason to believe income escaped.
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal confirmed AAC order August 21, 1950, holding s.34 as amended 1948 applied, within s.34(1)(b).
Assessee died; appellant (son) succeeded to estate.
Appellant applied under s.66(1) for reference to Patna HC; rejected February 27, 1951.
Appellant moved Patna HC under s.66(2); allowed December 15, 1951, directed Tribunal to refer question.
Tribunal stated case and referred question July 23, 1952: 'Whether in the circumstances of the case the assessment order under s.34 of the Act of the interest on arrears of rent is legal?'
Patna HC (V. Ramaswamy and C.P. Sinha JJ.) answered in favour of department April 7, 1954.
Appellant obtained certificate under s.66A(2) September 13, 1954.

legal_issues.text: True construction of s.34(1)(b) of Income-tax Act: Whether 'information in his possession' includes judicial decision on point of law (Privy Council reversing Patna HC), and whether income duly returned, considered, and excluded per binding HC decision has 'escaped assessment'.

petitioner_arguments.text: 'Information' in s.34(1)(b) means factual information only, not decision on point of law like Privy Council judgment.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Context of other sections like marginal notes ss.19A,20A,22(3),28; ss.33B,35 for revision/rectification

petitioner_arguments.text: Where income duly returned, assessment order passed, cannot be said to have 'escaped assessment' even if later legal view changes.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rajendranath Mukherjee v. CIT (1933) 61 IA 10; dictionary meaning of 'escaped'; requires no return or inadvertence

respondent_arguments.text: Privy Council decision is 'information' under s.34(1)(b), leading to belief income escaped assessment.
Income escaped assessment as not taxed due to earlier erroneous following of Patna HC decision, now reversed.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.34(1)(b); includes under-assessment due to legal error

court_reasoning.text: 'Information' in s.34(1)(b) includes information as to true state of law, including judicial decisions; context demands broad meaning, not limited to facts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Word depends on context; s.34(1)(b) covers low rate assessments implying legal info; Privy Council decision is such information.

court_reasoning.text: Income 'escaped assessment' even if returned and considered but not taxed due to erroneous legal view following binding HC decision later reversed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Escape not limited to no return or oversight; includes failure to tax assessable income erroneously.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Rajendranath Mukherjee: Applies only where proceedings pending, not final assessment; supports broader view.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Final assessment allows s.34 invocation post-error.

court_reasoning.text: Chatturam case inconsistent with narrow view; no need to limit to lacuna not attributable to authorities.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Escape includes chargeable income not validly assessed.

court_reasoning.text: Reviews High Court divergence but holds Patna HC correct: s.34(1)(b) satisfied.

holdings.text: Privy Council decision constitutes 'information' under s.34(1)(b); income escaped assessment as not taxed erroneously.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kamakshya Narain Singh v. Commissioner of Income Tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Held interest on arrears of agri rent taxable; basis for revised assessment
s.34 inapplicable only if proceedings pending without final order; not where final assessment erroneous
Income escapes if not included in made assessment

precedents_cited.case_name: Messrs. Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Chargeable income escaping due to invalid prior assessment invokes s.34

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Sir Mahomed Yusuf Ismail
Raghavalu Naidu & Sons v. Commissioner of Income-tax
Maharaja Bikram Kishore of Tripura v. Province of Assam
Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy v. Commissioner of I.T.
precedents_cited.relevance: Information includes true state of law from authoritative source

precedents_cited.case_name: Madan Lal v. Commissioner of I.T.
precedents_cited.relevance: s.34 covers unassessed items in return or cancelled assessments

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs escaped assessment, notices, appeals, references; amended 1939,1948; information leads to belief of escape permitting reassessment

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding Patna High Court; held revised assessment under s.34(1)(b) legal as Privy Council decision was 'information' giving reason to believe income escaped assessment.

key_quotes.text: "the word information in s. 34(1)(b) includes information as to the true and correct state of the law and so would cover information as to relevant judicial decisions."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "even in a case where a return has been submitted, if the Income-tax Officer erroneously fails to tax a part of assessable income, it is a case where the said part of the income has escaped assessment."
key_quotes.speaker: court
